summary: Email chain between Florence Hutner, General Counsel for the NYC Office of Chief Medical Examiner (OCME), and an unnamed federal prosecutor (likely from USAO-SDNY) regarding redactions to the Jeffrey Epstein autopsy report and related files. The prosecutor requests withholding of scene photos, 360 scans, and information from federal authorities, citing an ongoing criminal investigation.

persons.name: Florence Hutner
persons.role: General Counsel, Office of Chief Medical Examiner
persons.context: Represents the NYC Office of Chief Medical Examiner in communications with federal prosecutors regarding redactions to the Epstein autopsy file and scene materials.

persons.name: Rebekah
persons.context: Communicates with OCME's General Counsel to request specific redactions and withholding of materials (scene photos, 360 scan) from the Epstein file, citing an ongoing federal investigation.

connections.description: Engaged in official email correspondence regarding the handling and redaction of Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy report and related investigative materials.

events.title: Initial Redaction Request
events.description: Federal prosecutor (Rebekah) sends a secure message to OCME's General Counsel requesting redactions to the Epstein file, including scene photos and 360 scans.

events.title: Clarification on Redaction Scope and Duration
events.description: Florence Hutner seeks clarification on whether the redaction request includes OCME-taken photos/scans and whether it is temporary or permanent. The prosecutor confirms it includes the 360 scan and is not intended to be permanent.

events.title: Revised Report Provided
events.description: Prosecutor sends a revised OCME report with one redaction removed per OCME's request and asks OCME to notify recipients that redactions are due to an ongoing federal investigation.

locations: 421 E. 26th Street, New York, NY 10016 (Office of Chief Medical Examiner)
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USAO-SDNY) requested redactions of material obtained from federal authorities in the Jeffrey Epstein autopsy file, citing an ongoing criminal investigation.
Requested redactions included scene photographs and a 360-degree scan taken by the OCME, indicating federal authorities sought to control sensitive visual evidence.
The federal prosecutor clarified the redaction request was not intended to be permanent, only for the duration of the investigation.
OCME noted it would comply with any court order for the unredacted file but would notify federal prosecutors first to allow them to seek to preserve investigative confidentiality.
A voicemail from the MCC (Metropolitan Correctional Center, where Epstein died) was mentioned as being forwarded to the federal prosecutor for handling.
